word:
The Lord does not deny the charge of Joshua's unworthiness, but demonstrates that He has bought him with a price. He clothes him with His garments of righteousness, not putting these garments over the filthy garments of disobedience and transgression, but first He says, "Take away the filthy garments from him. And unto him He said, Behold, I have caused thine iniquity to pass from thee, and I will clothe thee with 


                                     -191- 

change of raiment. And I said, Let them set a fair mitre upon his head. So they set a fair mitre upon his head," upon which was written, "Holiness unto the Lord."
